page.title: 04Rare bats, plants & wildlife
page.content: Roundton Hill, 87 acres has been purchased for Â£31000 by the Montgomery -shire Trust for Nature Conservation. The hill has archaeological and geological interests as well as high landscape value and important wildlife . Rare plants developed on its volcanic derived soil include Monkey Flower, Mountain Pansy, Wild Thyme ,Rock Stonecrop, Carline Thistle and Hounds Tongue. There are over{100 recorded lichen {species. The hill supports breeding pairs of Kestrel, Wheatear, Whinchat, Tree Pipit and Redstart among other birds and{Peregrine Falcons}appear in winter . There is a colony of two bat species, the Daubenton's Bat and the globally rare{Lesser Horseshoe Bat.
